I've been running Idle Champions for approximately a year and a half at this point, and I suppose I should review it already.

The good: 

Character unlocks are free. In the current system, every month you can unlock three champions for free, so long as you complete a very easy quest (50 areas, which without any buffs means about an hour of progression). You earn Time Gate pieces in the course of regular gameplay, which you can exchange for the ability to unlock additional champions during events (three time pieces), or any champion of your choice through a time gate (six time pieces). You have the option of paying to unlock more champions, mostly with packs. 

Champions are diverse, giving everyone the ability to pick their favourites. Champions are split between famous characters in the DnD canon, characters from prominent DnD campaigns and fan fiction, and original creations of the developers. They come from diverse in-universe races and have their own abilities and mechanics. You can choose to field characters who are all the same affiliation, or all different races, or whatever, and more likely than not there is a champion with a bonus for having that type of team.

Various mechanics are introduced to make your party (parties, later) stronger. There are legendary items, automation cores with boosts to various statistics, and damage boosts from completing tasks or redeeming in-game rewards. All of these are free, and the pace with which you unlock things increases as your account grows more powerful (for example, I now earn a minimum of seven time gate pieces per week). Overall, it feels satisfying to progress, as you can see a real change in just what your champions can do.

The meh:
Overall, the different campaigns are modelled after famous Dungeons and Dragons campaigns, which is cool. In my first few quests I tried reading the storylines, but in the end it felt like they were just there to justify killing 25 monsters or collecting 25 items from said monsters. The gameplay loop is repetitive, with most challenge coming from restrictions that may be easy to deal with or may be painfully challenging (anything with perma-removal, for example). Personally, even with ridiculous iLevels I have trouble with the end-end game campaigns and variants.

The bad:
Progression is overall quite slow. It speeds up with the use of potions and other buffs, and there is a new campaign to allow additional unlocks, but in the end unless you are willing to spend real-world money you are unlikely to bring together the full roster within a year. Likewise, unlocking the feats and other bonuses for individual champions is time consuming. I get that this is the genre, and I get that a certain meta can mitigate its impact, but in the end I still ended up spending more than I'm willing to admit to build up my roster. 

The meta is very monolithic. If you want the best damage, there's a party for that, and if you vary it, you'll lose damage. If you want the most gold, there's a party for that.  If you're the type of player who just wants to play with your favourite characters (say, build everything around Karlach), you may find progress more difficult than someone choosing to field the meta.

Instead of releasing new and better goals to work toward in general with more layers to the gameplay like most idle games do, this game instead focus on puking out new streamer-based characters that are pretty much forgotten after the event is over in most case so often, a monthly update feel like nothing is really added to the game if you don't care about that new event character.

This is an example of an idle game that commits one of the cardinal sins of idle games: it demands your attention.
A lot of your attention. An increasingly ungainly amount of your attention.
Yet I like many others tolerated it anyway. The game was charming, and undoubtably a step up over Codename Entertainment's previous game. 
Boiling frogs though we were, it became increasingly unpleasant and unsatisfying to play the game.
Do your patron weeklies every week, click all the upgrades this reset, complete the seasonal events (that run almost monthly), click all your upgrades again, reset and adjust your three parties that run at the same time, click all the upgrades for all three parties because the automation won't do that until you upgrade your modron cores to level umpteen, click all your upgrades again, gnash your teeth at the idea of clearing that one objective that will require you to watch the game like a hawk for 40 minutes, click all your upgrades again, realize you HAVE to clear that one objective to unlock the new features, click all your upgrades again, CLICK THEM ALL, CLICK THEM AGAIN.

Did any of that help me clear areas I couldn't before? No? Why the hell not? Why do these upgrades feel like they do nothing?! Why does nothing I do feel like it increases my power incrementally IN THIS INCREMENTAL GAME?
Google formation guides. Find the one specific formation that trivializes the objective, that requires one or two very specific champions, using one very specific, and unintuitive specialization.

We don't get gold chests anymore from promo codes from videos and podcasts anymore. We get "electrum" chests.
Given that electrum is just gold watered down with silver, they are aptly named.

Now they've added another premium currency. Because the old currency, gems, were something we could earn through gameplay, and not drip fed day by day. It's an insult, but only a moderate one, because half the stuff in the shop just costs straight up cash anyway.

[list]

[*]Other oddities, but don't want this to become a book
